facts.text: Writ Petition No. 299 of 1969 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 299 of 1969. Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Petitioners were confirmed Tehsildars in the quondam State of Hyderabad prior to reorganisation on 1st November 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to the reorganisation of the States, which took place on 1st November, 1956 by virtue of the provisions of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, the petitioners were companyfirmed Tehsildars in the quondam State of Hyderabad which was then a Part B State.

facts.text: Rules of recruitment to Tehsildar posts in erstwhile Hyderabad: 1/3rd by promotion from lower ranks, 2/3rd by direct recruitment on competitive examination.

anchor.surface_text: The Rules of recruitment to the posts of Tehsildar which prevailed in the erstwhile State of Hyderabad provided that 1/3rd of the number of posts shall be filled by promotion from the lower ranks while the remaining 2/3rd shall be filled by direct recruitment on the basis of companypetitive examination.

facts.text: Petitioners belonged to directly recruited Tehsildars category.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners belonged to the latter category of directly recruited Tehsildars.

facts.text: Notification by Rajpramukh of Hyderabad on 15th September 1955: all vacancies in Deputy Collectors cadre filled only by promotion by selection from Tehsildars cadre.

anchor.surface_text: The next higher cadre above that of Tehsildars was the cadre of the Deputy Collectors and recruitment to, that cadre was governed by a numberification issued by the Rajpramukh of Hyde I rabid State on the 15th September, 1955. This numberification provided that all the vacancies of the cadre of Deputy Collectors shall be filled only by promotion by selection from the cadre of Tehsildars.

facts.text: Both Tehsildars and Deputy Collectors cadres were State cadres, common ground between parties.

anchor.surface_text: It was companymon ground between the parties that both the cadres of Tehsildars as well as Deputy Collectors were State cadres

facts.text: States Reorganisation Act, 1956 enacted by Parliament on 31st August 1956, effective 1st November 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On 31st August, 1956 the Parliament enacted the States Reorganisation Act, 1956 and that Act brought about reorganisation of almost all the States in India with effect from the appointed day, namely, 1st November, 1956.

facts.text: New State of Bombay constituted with territories from Bombay, Hyderabad, Madhya Pradesh, Saurashtra and Kutch.

anchor.surface_text: Section 8 companystituted a new State of Bombay with territories drawn from various existing States, namely, Bombay, Hyderabad, Madhya Pradesh, Saurashtra and Kutch.

facts.text: Government of Bombay Resolution dated 1st November 1956 divided new State into six divisions including Aurangabad Division with ex-Hyderabad territories plus East Khandesh.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Bombay, therefore, issued a Resolution, dated 1st November, 1956, dividing the territories of the new State into six divisions and placing each division in the charge of a Divisional differ. ... the territories drawn from the former Hyderabad State with the addition of East Khandesh District in Aurangabad Division.

facts.text: Allocated Government Servants Absorption, Seniority, Pay and Allowances Rules, 1957 made by Governor of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Bombay, therefore, made The Allocated Government Servants  Absorption, Seniority, Pay and Allowances  Rules, 1957, which We shall hereafter, for, the sake of companyvenience, refer to as the Rules of 1957.

facts.text: Petitioners and other Tehsildars from ex-Hyderabad absorbed as confirmed Grade II Mamlatdars w.e.f. 1st November 1956 in Aurangabad Division.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners and other Tehsildars allocated from the Ex-Hyderabad State were accordingly absorbed as companyfirmed Grade 11 Mamlatdars with effect from 1st November, 1956, and sense they were serving in one or the other of the districts of the Ex-Hyderabad State which were grouped together with East Khandesh District to companystitute Aurangabad Division, it was directed that they should be treated as Grade 11 Mamlatdars in the Aurangabad division.

facts.text: Government Resolution dated 21st October 1957 declared Mamlatdars in former Bombay equivalent to Tehsildars from ex-Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Bombay thereafter, by a Resolution dated 21st October, 1957, declared inter alia that the post of Mamlatdars in the former State of Bombay shall be deemed to be equivalent to the posts of Tehsildars allocated from the former State of Hyderabad.

facts.text: Rules of 30th July 1959 for recruitment to Deputy Collector posts: 50% nomination (direct), 50% promotion from Mamlatdars, with proviso half promotion vacancies for direct recruits with 7 years service.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 1 of these Rules is material and it may be reproduced as follows Appointment to the posts of Deputy Collector ,hall be made either by numberination or by promotion of suitable Mamlatdars. Provided that the ratio of appointment by numberination and by promotion shall, as far as practicable be 50 50. Provided further that half the vacancies reserved for appointment by promotion shall be filled by directly recruited Mamlatdars who have put in at least seven years service in the posts including the period spent on probation.

facts.text: Bombay High Court in Writ Petition No. 845 of 1967 (Kapor case) by judgment dated 23rd March 1968 declared second proviso to Rule 1 of 30th July 1959 rules void under Art. 16.

anchor.surface_text: but in writ Petition No. 845 of 1967 filed by one Kapor against the Commissioner of Aurangabad Division Ors., a Division Bench of the Bombay High Court, by its judgment , dated 23rd March, 1968, declared 2 23 that proviso void as being violative of the equal opportunity clause companytained in Art. 16 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Letter dated 18th October 1960 from Commissioner of Aurangabad Division to first petitioner stating Rules of 30th July 1959 not applicable to Marathwada officers, governed by ex-Hyderabad rules.

anchor.surface_text: That companytention was sought to be supported by reference to a letter dated 18th October, 1960 addressed by the Commissioner of Aurangabad Division to the first petitioner in which the Commissioner stated that the Rules of 30th July, 1959 are number applicable to Marathwada officers as they are governed by recruitment and promotion rules of Ex- Hyderabad State which are number yet unified by Government.

facts.text: Petitioners agreed to proceed on footing that Rules of 30th July 1959 governed recruitment throughout Bombay State.

anchor.surface_text: review of the companyent reasons given by the Bombay High Court in support of its decision the petitioners did number press their companytention and agreed to proceed on the footing that the Rules of 30th July, 1959 governed recruitment to the posts of Deputy Collector throughout the reorganised Bombay State.

facts.text: Cadre of Mamlatdars was divisional cadre, not State cadre, as per State Government practice and Rules of 19th November 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Now, according to the respondents, the cadre of Mamlatdars was a divisional cadre and number a State cadre ... The cadre of Mamlatdars always remained one and indivisible and it was a State cadre. Now, whatever be the companyrect position in law, ... There can, therefore, be numberdoubt that right from 1st November, 1956 the cadre of Mamlatdars was a divisional cadre and number a State cadre.

facts.text: Deputy Collectors cadre was a State cadre.

anchor.surface_text: It is equally clear from the Government Resolution dated 1st November, 1956 as well as the affidavits that the cadre of Deputy Columbus was a Stirling cadre.

facts.text: State Government followed procedure of preparing divisional select lists of Mamlatdars for promotion to officiating Deputy Collectors.

anchor.surface_text: The procedure that the State Government followed for making appointment to the posts of Deputy Collector by promotion of suitable Mamlatdars Tehsildars from and after 1st November, 1956 was that for each division a select,list of Mamlatdars Tehsildars companysidered fit for promotion as Deputy Collector was prepared by a revising companymittee every year

facts.text: Government Resolution dated 7th April 1961 laid down principles for preparation and revision of select lists of Mamlatdars for promotion to Deputy Collectors.

anchor.surface_text: On 7th April, 1961, the Government issued a Resolution laying down the principles for regulating preparation and revision of select list of Mamlatdars Tehsildars fit to be appointed as Deputy Collectors in the posts to be filled by promotion.

facts.text: Petitioners promoted as officiating Deputy Collectors in Aurangabad Division on different dates.

anchor.surface_text: Suffice it to point out that it was in accordance with the procedure that the petitioners were 2 2.5 promoted as officiating Deputy Collectors in the Aurangabad Division on different dates.

facts.text: Some allocated Mamlatdars/Tehsildars junior to petitioners in other divisions promoted as officiating Deputy Collectors earlier.

anchor.surface_text: The companysequence of the, adoption of this procedure, however, was that some of the allocated Mamlatdars Tehsildars, in other divisions, who were junior to the petitioners, became officiating Deputy Collectors earlier than the petitioners

facts.text: Petition filed on 14th July 1969.

anchor.surface_text: and yet the petitioner did number file the petition until 14th July, 1969.

facts.text: Promotions made by State Government were provisional, no crystallized rights.

anchor.surface_text: Here as admitted by the State Government in paragraph 55 of the affidavit in repeal promotions that have been made by the State Government area provisional and the position has number been crystallised to the prejudice of the petitioners.

facts.text: Court held procedure for promotions violative of Art. 16, directed readjustment with retrospective effect.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore, hold that the second proviso to Rule I of the Rules of 30th July, 1959 is void as being violative of Art. 16 of the Constitution. We also declare the Procedure for Promotion to the cadre of Deputy Collectors followed by the State Government to be invalid
Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

precedents.citation: Tilockchand Motichand v. H. B. Munishi

anchor.surface_text: question ,as pointed out by Hidayatullah, C.J., in Tilockchand Motichand v. H. B. Munishi 4  is one of discretion or this Court to follow from ,case to case. There is numberlower limit aid there is numberupper limit-. It will all depend on what the breach of the Fundamental Right and the remedy claimed are and how the delay arose. Here the petitioners were informed by the Commissioner, Aurangabad Division, by his letter dated 18th October, 1960 land also by the Secretary of the Revenue Department in January 1961 that the rules of recruitment to the posts of Deputy Collector in the reorganised State of Bombay had number yet been unified, and that the petitioners companytinued

precedents.cited_proposition: The rule against inquiring into related and stale claims is a rule of practice based on discretion; no inviolable rule that delay always bars relief; depends on facts, breach of right, and how delay arose.

anchor.surface_text: stated in the following terms by Hidayatullah, J. in Tilokchand v. H. B. Munshi 1  The party claiming Fundamental Rights must move the Court before other rights companye into existence. The action of companyrts cannot harm innocent parties if their rights emerge by reason of delay on the part of the person moving the Court. Sikri, J.,  as he then was , also restated the same principle in equally felicitous language when he said in S. Bose v. Union of India 2  It Would be unjust to deprive the respondents of the rights which have, accrued to them. Each person ought to be entitled to sit back and companysider that his appointment and promotion effected a long time ago would number be set aside after the lapse of a number of years.

precedents.cited_proposition: Party claiming fundamental rights must move court before other rights come into existence; courts cannot harm innocent parties due to delay.
precedents.cited_holding: The party claiming Fundamental Rights must move the Court before other rights come into existence.

precedents.citation: S. Bose v. Union of India 2

anchor.surface_text: Sikri, J.,  as he then was , also restated the same principle in equally felicitous language when he said in S. Bose v. Union of India 2  It Would be unjust to deprive the respondents of the rights which have, accrued to them. Each person ought to be entitled to sit back and companysider that his appointment and promotion effected a long time ago would number be set aside after the lapse of a number of years. Here as admitted by the State Government in paragraph 55 of the affidavit in repeal promotions that have been made by the State Government area provisional and the position has number been crystallised to the prejudice of the petitioners.

precedents.case_name: S. Bose v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Unjust to deprive respondents of rights accrued due to long delay in challenging appointments and promotions.
precedents.cited_holding: It would be unjust to deprive the respondents of the rights which have accrued to them.

precedents.citation: Shivdeo Singh v. State of Punjab 1

anchor.surface_text: the petitioners companyld always apply for a review of that impunities as did the parties in Shivdeo Singh v. State of Punjab 1 . The petitioners had this alternative legal remedy of review available to them and there was numberreason why, instead of pursuing that remedy, the petitioners should have filed the present petition under Art. 32. This companytention is also without force, and for three very good reasons. In the first place, it is difficult to see how the petitioners companyld have applied for review of the judgment of the Bombay High Court in Kapoors case.

precedents.case_name: Shivdeo Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Parties can apply for review of judgment.

precedents.citation: State of Mysore v. B Purohit 1

anchor.surface_text: well settled by the decision of the Court in State of Mysore v. B Purohit 1  that though a right to be companysidered for promotion is a companydition of service, mere chances of promo- tion are number. A rule which merely affects chances of promotion cannot be regarded as varying a companydition of service. In Purohits case, 1  the districtwise seniority of sanitary inspectors was changed to Statewise seniority,. and as a result of this change the respondents went down in seniority and became very junior.

precedents.case_name: State of Mysore v. B. Purohit
precedents.cited_proposition: Chances of promotion are not conditions of service; rule affecting chances does not vary conditions of service to attract proviso to s.115(7) States Reorganisation Act.
precedents.cited_holding: chances of promotion are not conditions of service

Re Ground C The first question that would logically seem to arise under the ground of challenge is whether in the reorganised State of Bombay the cadre of Mamlatdars was a State cadre or a divisional cadre.

precedents.case_name: S.M. Pandit v. State of Gujarat
precedents.cited_proposition: Directly recruited and promotee mamlatdars/tehsildars form one class; reservation of promotion quota for direct recruits violates Art. 16.

precedents.citation: B. N. Nagarajan v. State of Mysore 1

anchor.surface_text: it was companypetent to the State Government to take a decision in the exercise of its executive power under Art. 162 of the Constitution, vide B. N. Nagarajan v. State of Mysore 1  and Sant Ram v. State of Rajasthan  2 . The State Government accordingly decided by Government Resolution dated 1st November, 1956 that while recruitment to the posts of Mamlatdars should be on all State basis, the cadre of Mamlatdars should be according to the divisions.

precedents.case_name: B.N. Nagarajan v. State of Mysore
precedents.cited_proposition: State government competent to decide cadre structure in exercise of executive power under Art. 162 absent legislative rules.

precedents.citation: Sant Ram v. State of Rajasthan 2

anchor.surface_text: vide B. N. Nagarajan v. State of Mysore 1  and Sant Ram v. State of Rajasthan  2 . The State Government accordingly decided by Government Resolution dated 1st November, 1956 that while recruitment to the posts of Mamlatdars should be on all State basis, the cadre of Mamlatdars should be according to the divisions. It was companytended on behalf of the petitioners that the companystitution of Mamlatdars into divisional cadres was companytrary to the Bombay Civil Services Classification and Recruitment Rules which were statutory rules made by the Governor under s. 241 of the Government of India Act, 1935.

precedents.case_name: Sant Ram v. State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: State government competent to decide cadre structure in exercise of executive power under Art. 162 absent legislative rules.

precedents.citation: Ram Saran v. Deputy Inspector General of police 1

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, however, relied very heavily on the decision of this Court in Ram Saran v. Deputy Inspector General of police 1  and companytended that this decision gives approval to the mode of promotion adopted by the State Government in the present case. We do number think so. Read superficially it might appear that this decision supports the companytention of the respondents, but if we scrutinise It closely, it would be apparent that number only it does number render any assistance to the respondents but actually goes against them.

precedents.case_name: Ram Saran v. Deputy Inspector General of Police
precedents.cited_proposition: Tiered promotion system (district/range/state) justified for administrative efficiency and local knowledge in police force.

precedents.citation: Ram Saran v. Deputy Inspector General of police 1

anchor.surface_text: reasoning of the decision in Ram Sarans case 1  that far from negativing the companytention of the petitioners, it goes a long way towards supporting it. In Ram Sarans case 1  the cadre of Sub- Inspectors was a range cadre and promotion to that cadre in each range was made on the basis of select  1 1964 7 S.C.R. 228. list of approved Head Constables from that particular range. This mode of promotion which companyfined promotional Head Constables to Sub-Inspectors within the range was upheld by this Court because it was calculated to make available the advantage of local knowledge in a post where such local knowledge would be useful in promoting the interest of administrative efficiency of the police force.

precedents.case_name: Ram Saran v. Deputy Inspector General of Police
precedents.cited_proposition: Rangewise promotion to range cadre upheld due to local knowledge needs.

anchor.surface_text: the ratio of the decision in Ram Sarans case 1  that far from negativing the companytention of the petitioners, it goes a long way towards supporting it.

precedents.case_name: Ram Saran v. Deputy Inspector General of Police
precedents.cited_proposition: Promotion to state cadre must be statewide, not divisional/rangewise unless justified by cadre structure.

justification_sets.label: Section 241, Government of India Act 1935 support

anchor.surface_text: We therefore, hold that the second proviso to Rule I of the Rules of 30th July, 1959 is void as being violative of Art. 16 of the Constitution. We also declare the Procedure for Promotion to the cadre of Deputy Collectors followed by the State Government to be invalid on the grand that it denies equality of opportunity of promotion ago is therefore hit by Art 16 of the Constitution. The Government Resolution dated 7th April 1961 must also. be quashed and set aside for the same reason.

outcome.relief_summary: Second proviso to Rule 1 of Rules dated 30.07.1959 declared void; promotion procedure to Deputy Collectors declared invalid under Art. 16; GR dated 07.04.1961 quashed and set aside; directions issued for readjustment of promotions and confirmations retrospectively with benefits to petitioners (no arrears prior to filing); some grounds rejected.
directions: State Government to readjust promotions as officiating Deputy Collectors and confirmations in cadre of Deputy Collectors per principles in judgment.
Readjustment with retrospective effect; petitioners to get seniority, pay and allowances from dates they would have been promoted on correct basis.
No arrears of pay/allowances for period prior to filing of petition.
First respondent to pay costs of petition to petitioners.
